I like the hunting methode of the Tentacled snake (Erpeton tentaculatum).
The Snake lurkes under water using it's tail as anchor, forming an J shape with their body. When a fish is in the right position they do a little movement with their body. That triggers the escape reflex of the fish called c-start, right in the direction of the snakes head where the snake can easily catch them. It's realy cool that these snakes even anticipat the movement of their prey.


I saw them once in a documentary.

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tentacled_snake

Stoats are the animal worlds, serial killers.  I can NOT remember what animal doc it was but he said that if they were 75-100lbs animals they would have killed almost everything on land or anywhere it could reach. I had one in my backyard when I was young. It lived in a hole under a log a few feet into the woods behind my house. And WITHOUT FAIL every single day you could sit at the window and watch it kill EVERYTHING it seen. MANY times we had to go in the back n pick up the dead birds n chipmunks and mice and any lil animal it could grab and a bunch of times full grown rabbits. And as CRAZY as it sounds one time I found a dead female red tail hawk. It got it as the hawk grabbed a large mouse. While the hawk was leaned over with its head down the lil serial killer jumped on its back and just started crunching n ripping at its neck n head and in less then a min the hawk was dead. And I ALWAYS thought that they would NEVER go after a bird of pray since I thought that since hawks will eat them if giving the chance that the stoats would be scared of hawks. NOPE!!!

It's kinda weird how the adaptations for long distance running saved our lives millions of years ago because we could run down prey without expending more calories than we are getting from the prey, but now that we don't have to run down prey those calorie conservation adaptations are killing many of us from medical conditions directly related to the fact that our bodies having evolved to hold on to and conserve those calories. Especially in this country where so many of the foods are super calorie dense and we as Americans tend to lead a more sedentary lifestyle.

I did that last one to my dog in high school. He had a tendency to make a break for freedom at any point someone left the back door open too long. One of those times was around 2am in the summer.

I was trying to sleep. My mother was afraid of him being taken to the pound. Again. Mostly because she didn't want to pay the fee.

I didn't feel like doing the whole "Walking around and calling his name bit" and I couldn't drive at the time. Plus, he wouldn't come anyways. The aggravating mutt (I still love him to this day) was just sitting right outside the boundary of our backyard. Every time I tried to walk close to him, he would go a little further away.

So; I started jogging. He ran and I kept jogging after him with the determination that I wasn't stopping until I had him. It wasn't a hard run and I was in running shape back then. Wow I was young.

He had been outside and generally raising hell for two hours before I had been called to the task so he was already more weary. It took me about a mile and a half and finally he just stopped and lay down.

That was the only time I had ever seen my dog truly afraid of me. Granted, I was pretty upset with him. He had dragged me out of bed after all. It was the only time he had ever tried to actually snap at me.

So I booped him under his snout (gently), and picked him up like a brindle, panting, purple-tongued sheep and carried him home. We both collapsed on my bed after some water and went to sleep.

How terrifying for animals. They see humans and run away and after a few minutes they stop to catch their breath. Then two dark figures appear in the distance coming closer.
